Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: The Pygmy Borers (Col., Scolytinae: Cryphalini): revision of genera, evolution of the genome, and modernization of insect systematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bark beetles are among the most damaging pests, and a diverse group of insects which are difficult to identify. This project will revise the classification and evolutionary history of one of the largest and most important bark beetle groups: Cryphalini, the Pygmy Borers.
The project will 1) revise the classification of Cryphalini genera using a molecular phylogeny, 2) analyze populations of putatively global cryphaline species (some of the most widespread insects on Earth) to test whether they are true species or clusters of cryptic species, and 3) reconstruct the evolution of genome copy number in Pygmy Borers (in some genera, males have only one copy of each chromosome), and test whether deviations are associated with manipulative bacterial parasites. Our approach integrates next-generation sequencing, automated matrix-based taxonomy, and a large global network of collaborators, including ?citizen collectors?.

Our high-throughput methodology represents a new cost-efficient approach to diverse but understudied groups of organisms. Non-academics will benefit from the new identification capacity. A single cryphaline species (i.e., the Coffee Berry Borer) causes $500,000,000 annual damages, yet quarantine officers have no tools to distinguish it from other cryphalines. The broad public will benefit from a new Citizen Science project ?Bark beetles in your backyard?.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bark beetles are among the most damaging pests in the world, but also a diverse group of insects with many unique biological features. We have revised the classification and evolutionary history of one of the largest and most important bark beetle groups that also happens to be the least known: Cryphalini, the Pygmy Borers. With 702 known species and many more still undescribed, Cryphalini include many destructive pests, but also as many interesting cases of unusual symbioses, genetic systems, and mating curiosities.

We have used the most modern approach to recreating evolutionary history of organisms – the comparison of sub-sampled genomes via “hybrid anchored enrichment”. The effort was expanded from Cryphalini to all bark beetles collected from worldwide tropical forests. We inferred the first robust phylogeny of bark beetles, which allowed us to not only put correct names on species and genera, but also study the evolution of natural history innovations in these insects.

One of the major “innovations” studied here was haplo-diploidy, the unusual but prolific reproduction strategy in which males are rare, and have only one copy of genetic information, that from their mother. We discovered that it evolved six times among bark beetles! Another question was whether this genetic strategy is caused by symbiotic bacteria, including Wolbachia which cause sex bias in some other insects. We discovered that Wolbachia is present, indeed abundant in many bark beetle groups, but it does not seem to correlate with haplo-diploidy.

Some bark beetles, including many Pygmy borers, are global “super-tramps”, travelling around the world and establishing populations everywhere. We have mapped the genetic structure of such species, and discovered that one of them (Xylosandrus crassiusculus) is actually composed of two distinct populations, and one of these populations was repeatedly introduced into the U.S.

Our capacity to study the genetic structure of bark beetle populations also allowed us to clarify the identity of several major pests. For example, we discovered that, what was previously thought to be one pest species on mango trees, is actually three different lineages. One is the real pest that spreads mango wilt, another one is widespread but harmless, and a third one attacks fig trees, not mangos.

Our project went far beyond the research objects. The first Broader Impacts sub-project Backyard Bark Beetles has grown into a nationally recognized citizen science project, featured on SciStarter.com. Its website www.backyardbarkbeetles.org, its Facebook page and Twitter account are visited by more than 20,000 visitors each year. We have also physically attended dozens of local or regional meetings in schools and volunteer clubs, and educated over 3000 kids and adults about forest insects.

The second Broader Impacts sub-project Bark and Ambrosia Beetle Academy (http://ambrosiasymbiosis.org/academy/) has evolved into a globally renowned workshop. Offered every two years in the US and once in Ecuador for nearly 100 national and international participants, the Academy unites scientists, government entomologists and practitioners into a global community of bark beetle researchers and educators.

Lastly, one of the indirect goals of the project was to effectively connect the global community of bark beetle researchers, and we believe that we have succeeded. Our frequent publications, talks, and the online networking efforts (including https://www.facebook.com/groups/FrassAndNoodles/) helped to transform a formerly disarrayed field into an interconnected global community of bark beetle researchers, students, government entomologists, and fans.
